column4: don_andrez this command sudo sysctl -A | grep vmi returns errors. "error: "Invalid argument" reading key "fs.binfmt_misc.register""
don_andrez sluggo All hail the mighty sluggo... his command returned`CONFIG_VMI=y' Thanks sluggo. That should answer don_andrez question.
again, i'm not sure how vbox really works - so i cant say for sure how to remedy it, maybe the official way to get it working properly is to reboot, but then i'd say it wasn't written properly :)
you've probably found a bug, you might like to report it
perhaps. But it doesn't take away from your larger point, that I restart too often :)
I usually only reboot my machine if i want to add hardware to it or do a kernel upgrade - but then again, i dont run much exotic software

the best way to do this is to use gpg with your mail client .. what you essentially do is encrypt the file using the other person's public key, the only person in the world then able to decrypt the file is that person, using his private key ... but this requires he use pgp/gpg too
another way is to use something like openssl to encrypt the file using a passphrase, but the other person needs to have openssl installed too
well, when I right-click on the file and choose encrypt... how is that different from openssl
i'm not really sure what that does, i don't use gnome .. i'd imagine it used openssl, but i can't be sure
are you prompted for a password/passphrase when you choose that option?
Hmm... no I'm prompted for a recipient, but the list is empty.
hrrm, not sure then, you need to get someone who knows gnome to help you out there.
maybe the documentation on gnome.org helps?
